abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that concerning
            project preparation, this operation underlines the
            importance of ensuring quality at entry including the need
            to have a solid assessment of project readiness for
            implementation. With a flaw in the initial project design
            and whatever the ensuing effort to put the Project on track,
            the price to pay would be high and the results limited. A
            clear lesson from the experience in Ghana is that careful
            attention to the sequencing of the reform is essential
            within the individual component, with other related project
            components and with other reforms being undertaken outside
            the project. The ambition attached to the original project
            design exceeded any reasonable expectation given the
            experience of such budget preparation and public expenditure
            management systems in Ghana and elsewhere. Another lesson is
            the confirmation of the need for sufficient attention to
            institutional issues at the initial stages of project design.
